forecast.rationale: The evidence overwhelmingly points toward Modi not attending. My research assistant confirms that as of early June 2025, India has not received an official invitation to the G7 summit scheduled for June 15-17 in Canada, with only 12 days remaining. Multiple credible sources (The Tribune, Hindustan Times) report no advance preparations are underway, which is contrary to standard protocol for high-level visits that typically require weeks of planning for security and logistics. Notably, Canada has invited other non-G7 countries including Australia, Ukraine, South Africa, and Brazil, but conspicuously not India. The status quo strongly favors a 'No' outcome, and good forecasters weight the status quo heavily as the world changes slowly. For Modi to attend would require: (1) a sudden diplomatic breakthrough in Canada-India relations, which are currently strained, (2) an invitation issued within the next 2-3 days, (3) completion of security and logistical preparations in an unprecedented 9-10 day timeframe, and (4) India's willingness to accept what appears to be a last-minute, potentially face-losing invitation. My forecast is not lower (below 5%) because there is still technically sufficient time for an invitation, diplomatic situations can occasionally shift rapidly, and India remains strategically important enough that emergency outreach is possible. My forecast is not higher (above 10%) because the timeline is extremely compressed, no invitation has been extended despite Canada inviting multiple other countries, advance preparations are absent, and India-Canada relations remain tense. For me to update upward, I would need to see: an official invitation extended to India, announcements of security preparations beginning, or diplomatic signals of reconciliation. For me to update downward, the passage of another 5-7 days without an invitation would make attendance virtually impossible.
